hackathon-description-text: Build the coolest software and hardware projects you can think of! You will learn useful skills, work with amazing people, and win awesome prizes along the way. We encourage all students of any skill level or major to join.
hackathon-rules:
HOW BIG SHOULD TEAMS BE? CAN I DO IT ALONE?
Teams should be at most 4 people. You can work alone but teams are HIGHLY recommended.
WHAT'S THE FORMAT OF THE HACKATHON?
"Anything goes!" Web, desktop, mobile, and hardware projects are all welcome. (All hacks should be tech-related, though.) Projects will be judged based on creativity, technical difficulty, polish, and usefulness.
ARE WE ALLOWED TO BUILD ON PAST PROJECTS? OTHER CODE?
We strongly discourage building off of existing projects you've worked on. Using third–party APIs and libraries is encouraged, as long as they're accessible by everyone else as well.
 
CODE OF CONDUCT: 
We take this very seriously. http://static.mlh.io/docs/mlh-code-of-conduct.pdf

hackathon-prizes.prize-title: TowerSec Most Novel Use of an Embedded System (such as a Raspberry Pi, Microcontroller etc.)

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Raspberry Pi, Spark Photon or ESP8266 for each team members!
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Bookholders Longest Stack Name on a Raspberry Pi

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: 1TB Dell Portable Hard Drive for each team member!
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Use of Amazon Web Services

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Domain.com swag bag for each member.
A GitHub OctoCat statue for each developer!
$25 gift cards to Best Buy for each team member

hackathon-location-google-maps: https://maps.google.com/?q=1000 Hilltop Cir, Catonsville, MD 21228, USA

hackathon-judging-criteria.judging-criterion: Is the hack Technically interesting or difficult? Is it just a wrapper on an API, or were there real technical challenges to overcome?
Is the hack usable in its current state? Is the user experience smooth? Does everything appear to work? Is it well designed?
Is it a unique idea? Has it been done before? Does it do something novel, or at least take a new approach to an old problem?
Is the hack practical? Is it something people would actually use? Does it fulfill a real need people have?

hackathon-description-header: HackUMBC gives you 24 hours to learn new skills, make friends, create your wildest idea, and share it with the world.
